baby: Conception is happening! The fertilized egg (zygote) begins its journey to the uterus.
mom: You may not notice any changes yet. Your body is preparing the uterine lining for implantation.
nutrition: Start taking folic acid (400mcg daily). Eat leafy greens, lentils, and fortified cereals.
warning_signs: No specific warning signs at this stage. Focus on healthy habits.

baby: The embryo is the size of a poppy seed. The neural tube (future brain and spine) is forming.
mom: You might notice a missed period, mild cramping, or breast tenderness. A pregnancy test may show positive.
nutrition: Increase iron-rich foods (spinach, beans). Stay hydrated with 8-10 glasses of water.
warning_signs: Heavy bleeding or severe cramping — contact your doctor immediately.

baby: Baby is about the size of a raspberry. Tiny fingers and toes are forming. The heart is beating!
mom: Morning sickness may peak. Fatigue and frequent urination are common. Your first prenatal visit is due.
nutrition: Eat small, frequent meals to manage nausea. Ginger tea can help. Avoid raw fish and unpasteurized dairy.
warning_signs: Severe vomiting preventing any food/liquid intake. Spotting with pain.

baby: Baby is the size of a lime (~5cm). Organs are fully formed and beginning to function. Reflexes are developing.
mom: Nausea often starts to ease. You may notice a small baby bump. Energy levels may improve.
nutrition: Calcium is crucial now — include milk, yogurt, or fortified alternatives. Aim for 1000mg daily.
warning_signs: Persistent headaches, blurred vision, or sudden swelling in hands/face.

baby: Baby is about the size of an avocado. They can make facial expressions and may start sucking their thumb!
mom: Welcome to the 'golden trimester'! Many women feel more energetic. You may feel the first flutters of movement.
nutrition: Omega-3 fatty acids support brain development — eat fish (low mercury), walnuts, or take supplements.
warning_signs: Any fluid leaking from the vagina. Persistent lower back pain.

baby: Halfway there! Baby is the size of a banana (~25cm). You'll likely have your anatomy scan this week.
mom: You can clearly feel baby movements now. Your uterus is at navel level. Skin changes (linea nigra) may appear.
nutrition: Increase protein intake (70g/day) — lean meat, eggs, tofu, legumes. Vitamin D is important too.
warning_signs: Reduced fetal movement after feeling regular kicks. Painful urination (possible UTI).

baby: Baby weighs about 600g and is developing a sleep-wake cycle. Lungs are developing surfactant.
mom: Braxton Hicks contractions may start. Glucose screening test is usually done around now.
nutrition: Monitor sugar intake. Eat complex carbohydrates (whole grains, sweet potatoes) for sustained energy.
warning_signs: Signs of preterm labor: regular contractions, pelvic pressure, watery vaginal discharge.

baby: Third trimester begins! Baby can open their eyes and weighs about 1kg. Brain is developing rapidly.
mom: Shortness of breath and heartburn increase as baby grows. Sleep may become uncomfortable.
nutrition: Iron needs increase significantly — eat red meat, beans, and pair with vitamin C foods for absorption.
warning_signs: Severe headache, vision changes, upper abdominal pain — could indicate pre-eclampsia. Seek care immediately.

baby: Baby is about 42cm and weighs ~1.8kg. They're practicing breathing movements and can hear your voice clearly.
mom: Frequent bathroom trips return. Swelling in ankles is common. You should start counting kicks daily.
nutrition: Magnesium helps with leg cramps — eat nuts, seeds, dark chocolate. Continue high iron and calcium.
warning_signs: Fewer than 10 kicks in 2 hours. Sudden severe swelling. Vaginal bleeding.

baby: Baby is almost full-term (~47cm, ~2.7kg). They're moving into head-down position for delivery.
mom: You may feel 'lightening' as baby drops lower. Pelvic pressure increases. Nesting instinct may kick in!
nutrition: Eat dates (6 per day from week 36) — studies show they may help with cervical ripening. Stay well hydrated.
warning_signs: Water breaking (gush or trickle of fluid). Regular contractions every 5 minutes.

baby: Full term! Baby weighs about 3.4kg and is 50cm long. They are ready to meet you!
mom: Due date week! You may experience the mucus plug release, increased contractions, and lower back pain.
nutrition: Eat light, easily digestible meals. Pack hospital snacks (energy bars, juice). Stay hydrated for labor.
warning_signs: Contractions 5 minutes apart lasting 1 minute for 1 hour — time to go to the hospital!
